name: Jurassic Beast - Epic
description: With a mixture of spectacular views, leg-pumping climbs and historical scenery, the Wiggle Jurassic Beast Sportive has become a ‘must do’ ride for many cyclists and one of the most popular events in our sportive calendar.  Starting out at the National Tank Museum in Bovingdon, Epic riders split straight away as the route heads north and up through a series of unspoilt Dorset villages, skirting around the base of menacing-looking hills in the region, throwing in a short and sharp climb every now and again – while you’ll pass the first after mile 10 just past Milton Abbas.  Continuing on, the next spike in gradient will follow just a few miles later, just before Shillingstone, followed by another as you head towards Ansty Cross.  Pushing on through Dorset, you’ll continue to ride through the Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and tackle another series of short and steep climbs.  Soon enough, it’s time to head towards the coast and take in the terrific views of Corfe Castle, Lulworth Cove and Poole Harbour that the Jurassic Beast sportive is renowned for. Views stretch out towards the Isle of Wight and make up for the up-and-down nature of the final few miles. Don’t miss this Sportive – it’s a ride worth taking.

name: Le Classique
description: The Altura Le Classique Sportive is one of our fastest-selling sportives. Bag a place on this ride in France as soon as you can for a ticket to one of the best overseas one-day bike trips there is.  After meeting in Dover, we’ll provide you with your rider number on board the ferry and you’ll be free to begin pedalling as soon as we disembark on the other side of the English Channel. This event serves as a perfect introduction to riding on the Continent, offering participants a snapshot of rural France — the spiritual home of cycling.  Leaving Calais, you’ll follow the coastline westwards and, despite exposure to invariably blustery conditions, the views out over the channel will keep you buoyed for the remainder of the ride.  A series of quaint and quintessentially French towns and villages are passed — in between which lies a series of short and punchy climbs, joined by a network of small and narrow byways. Such is the width of these lanes you’ll find cars around here are decidedly absent but in the rare event of meeting one expect an encouraging “Allez!” from the drivers. This is, after all, France, where cycling is the national pastime.  Following a clockwise route around the Nord Pas de Calais department, the atmospheric rural areas here boast a charm exclusive to Northern France and will leave you with fond memories and no doubt a photo or two.  And now, as you approach the end of the route — buffeted about by headwinds as you rejoin the coastal roads — the grand finale lies in wait. Indeed, today’s most demanding appointment in Ecalles is positioned agonisingly close to the finish line. It’s tough but manageable — and summiting it leaves you with a sprint to the international port where we’ll get you on the next available ferry home for a well-deserved verre du vin.  If you've ever considered cycling in France, signing up to Le Classique Sportive is your chance to join hundreds of other cyclists on carefully selected routes, complete with mechanical and medical support, to enjoy the French countryside from the saddle. That and the fact your travel to and from France is all booked for you, what are you waiting for?

name: County Durham Dynamo - Epic
description: The Wiggle County Durham Dynamo, now in its second year, explores the hills and rolling roads of the southern-most countryside in County Durham. Reaching out to the North Pennines Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty at its furthest point, the route takes in some excellent climbs and some even better views.  Heading out from the home of the Darlington Mowden Park RFC, we bear north almost immediately, taking in the villages of Piercebridge and Staindrop, at which point the Short route splits and heads south.  The route continues west, tracking along to Kinninvie before heading north to the second split of the day, from here the Epic riders take a northerly tack passing through the village of Woodlands, continuing north, riding the edge of Hamsterley Forest before descending into Wolsingham. All the while the Standard riders head west to the small village of Mickleton to rejoin the Epic route.  As you leave the main road at Frosterley you are faced with a tough climb to the top of Hill End, with views out over Bollihope Common and the burn at the bottom of the descent. We ride south through Bollihope Common and pass by Middleton-in-Teesdale, before climbing out of the valley towards Barnard Castle. The final push back west stretches through a series of quaint English villages typical of the County Durham area.

name: Dartmoor Demon - Epic
description: Be prepared for an eyeful of Devon’s most glorious countryside in the Sigma Sports Dartmoor Demon. Straight from the off, you’ll be marvelling at the stunning Haldon Forest before heading down the River Teign.  It won't be long before you see the last of civilisation for a few hours as the circle around and through Dartmoor National Park begins, which lead through quiet and sprawling lanes on undulating terrain.  As much as the moors are sparse, there’s enough to keep you interested as you tackle the short and punchy climbs throughout – not forgetting a few long ascents as well. Old brick bridges and deserted roads make up most of the scenery on the road as you pass through the National Park – before meeting and skirting around the ever-eerie and element-exposed HM Prison Dartmoor in Princetown.  Flatter terrain waits in the far side of the Park, while the pinch point of Buckfastleigh signals the start of the most testing climbing action that this event has to offer. Crossing the River Dart is a prelude to the 25% climb that faces rides coming out of Poundsgate.  With the toughest part of the Dartmoor Demon Sportive done, it’s not over yet as two more 20% ascents sit between the toughest climbing of the day and a finisher’s medal. Heading back through Haldon Forest to the racecourse finish point, every rider crossing the line will have a story to tell from a tough but rewarding day out riding.

name: Kent Classic - Epic
description: Setting off from the village of Lingfield you will be out in the country before you know it, as all three routes head south to Wych Cross taking in the first of many quaint little villages you’ll cycle through during the ride. It is around this point, at the 7-mile mark, that you’ll tackle the first real steady climb of the day.  At Colemans Hatch, the Short route riders can relax knowing that they’ve completed the hardest part of their ride with only two steady climbs left to tackle. It’s at this point they will split off from the other routes as they head North towards Edenbridge.  Epic and Standard riders, however, go straight into the steepest climb of the day as they pass through Newbridge and make their way toward Royal Tunbridge Wells.  Shortly past Groombridge, the course divides again as the Standard riders head north with Royal Tunbridge Wells to their East. They won’t see the Epic riders again until they reach Sevenoaks, having taken in Langton Green, Penshurst and Chiddingstone, to name but a few of the villages along the route  Epic riders continue East as they ride into the High Weald Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. There are a few short climbs along this section of the course that might take you by surprise. Notable elevation changes occur around Goudhurst, another just past Yalding and a third at Roughway. These should serve as nice testers to get you warmed up for the final climb at Dunks Green, that ascends steadily for several miles before peaking at Sevenoaks Common. It is here that you’ll embark on a nice descent before re-joining the Standard riders once again. From here, it’s a 14-mile ride back to Lingfield, via the village of Edenbridge, with no major challenges looming.  With three routes to choose from, The Wiggle Kent Classic Sportive has something to offer cyclists of all abilities, whether you’re a beginner or someone that likes a bit of a challenge - all the while soaking in some of the best countryside Britain has to offer. After all, Kent is called The Garden of England for a reason

name: The Arrow - Epic
description: Taking its name from the typically flat lands in Lincolnshire and the surrounding area, you’ll glide through the level plains on the Sigma Sports' Arrow Sportive like a dart through the air – save for an unlikely uphill test that waits for tired legs at the end of the ride. You’ll start out on Market Rasen Racecourse and head south, straight onto quiet roads. The first part of the course points more downhill than the even gradient the area is famous for – so make the most of the slightly sloping angle as you pass through sleepy village after sleepy village, linked by unspoilt country lanes. Heading towards Lincoln, the first climb of the day will present itself just after Canwick. It’s steep but quick and easy to deal with after a little exertion.  Once this has passed, it’s onto the long, straight open roads as far south as Ruskington in the North Kesteven District – giving you through opportunity to set your own pace on terrain that remains relatively flat.  Crossing over a series of dykes and small rivers, you’ll head to Woodhall Spa and Bucknall, where the terrain slowly begins to rise, as you cling to the Lincolnshire Wolds for the next 15 miles until the finish line is in sight, from here it is a flat run in to Market Rasen.

name: Ups and Downs - Epic
description: Inevitably, the clue is in the name of the Wiggle Ups and Downs Sportive. It’s an early-season test like few others and its many climbs and descents will get the heart racing no matter what. The tight and technical turns in the fast country lanes add to a great variety of climbing roads in the North and South Downs on a great test of a route.  The routes explore hidden country lanes in and around Surrey before cropping up near Godalming – you won’t enter the urban area, instead, it’s time to head to the South Downs. You’ll go as far down as Wisborough Green, and into Sussex, before surfacing and edging back into Surrey, where the remainder of the testing hills present themselves near the end of the route

name: Ridgeway Rouleur - Epic
description: The UKCE Ridgeway Rouleur offers the best of Oxfordshire’s stunning rolling countryside, passing through picturesque villages filled with quaint cottages and impressive manor houses.  Standard and Epic course riders head west straight away, making their way up the iconic landscape of the Wittenham Clumps, with stunning panoramic views of south Oxfordshire, before crossing the River Thames and winding out through small villages on quiet roads.  From Woolstone to Wantage, the Standard and Epic routes wind along and across the Ridgeway – Britain’s oldest road – which has been used by both ancient and modern traffic for more than 5,000 years. At the village of Uffington, riders are rewarded with a spectacular view of the mystical White Horse chalk remains.  While the short route passes through Wallingford, the best surviving Saxon Fortified town in England, all routes head towards Watlington, an area standing between the Vale of Oxford and the steep slopes of the Chilterns, Epic riders head towards the chalk grassland of Aston Rowant Nature Reserve before looping back below the traditional market town of Thame.  All routes rejoin and head back towards Oxford passing Chalgrove Airfield, next to a civil war battle site. With rolling quiet roads and superb views across areas steeped in history, the Ridgeway Rouleur presents an ideal sportive to take in the very best areas of Oxfordshire while giving your all on the mixed terrain in the area.

name: Forest of Bowland - Epic
description: The Altura Forest of Bowland Sportive is a tough early-season test for the legs with over 8,000ft of climbing to tackle but you will be given just reward with superb sights and scenery as the Cumbria sportive rolls through two Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty.  At the start, the sportive leads out towards Milnthorpe Sands as the route enters its first Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty of the day, Arnside and Silverdale.  After a stint on the River Kent, the route dives south to Carnforth and on to the first course split. Short riders peel off west while Standard and Epic participants bear south to our second AONB of the day, the Forest of Bowland, where the course centres its loop for much of the rest of the ride, while also bringing about one of the toughest challenges in the Trough of Bowland.  Winding its way through the surrounding fells and rivers, the course gives some of the best views the area has to offer. Reaching Dunsop Bridge the course splits for the last time as Standard riders head west and Epic entrants continue south for an additional 1,500ft of climbing.  Reaching the edge of Clitheroe, the sportive heads north, climbing up to the top of the Newton Fells before descending to continue onto Slaidburn. The return leg across the Forest of Bowland climbs higher than before, granting you glorious views of the Tatham Fells until you reach High Bentham, at which point the route heads east through the village of Hornby.  Leaving the National Park at Gressingham, the route continues to wind its way north for the final miles until reaching the finish line, where a medal and t-shirt will be given to riders upon completing this rewarding riding test.

name: Forest of Bowland - Standard
description: The Altura Forest of Bowland Sportive is a tough early-season test for the legs with over 8,000ft of climbing to tackle but you will be given just reward with superb sights and scenery as the Cumbria sportive rolls through two Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty.  At the start, the sportive leads out towards Milnthorpe Sands as the route enters its first Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty of the day, Arnside and Silverdale.  After a stint on the River Kent, the route dives south to Carnforth and on to the first course split. Short riders peel off west while Standard and Epic participants bear south to our second AONB of the day, the Forest of Bowland, where the course centres its loop for much of the rest of the ride, while also bringing about one of the toughest challenges in the Trough of Bowland.  Winding its way through the surrounding fells and rivers, the course gives some of the best views the area has to offer. Reaching Dunsop Bridge the course splits for the last time as Standard riders head west and Epic entrants continue south for an additional 1,500ft of climbing.  Reaching the edge of Clitheroe, the sportive heads north, climbing up to the top of the Newton Fells before descending to continue onto Slaidburn. The return leg across the Forest of Bowland climbs higher than before, granting you glorious views of the Tatham Fells until you reach High Bentham, at which point the route heads east through the village of Hornby.  Leaving the National Park at Gressingham, the route continues to wind its way north for the final miles until reaching the finish line, where a medal and t-shirt will be given to riders upon completing this rewarding riding test.

name: New Forest Spring - Epic
description: The Wiggle New Forest Spring Sportive is one of our most popular event and has become a welcome start-of-season test for for many cyclists. Due to its popularity, the event runs on both a Saturday and Sunday – and usually sells out before the day. Take this as a sign that you’ll get your cycling fill from this sportive, which takes in much of the stunning New Forest on the route.  As you ride and take in the views in the rolling scenery, there will be a number of hills to challenge your legs – plus a test to come near the end – with short and sharp climbs popping up every now and again to keep you on your toes. Beautiful New Forest villages of Sway, Beaulieu and Lepe are passed through before you head north and back into the centre of the district.  Quickly in and out of central point Lyndhurst, you’ll soon take on the events major climb of the day, just outside Nomansland. It’s steep, but fairly short, so you should be able to dispose of this quickly and continue on your way. From here, it’s downhill all the way – with one spiky hill exception around Stuckton and the final feed stop – as you roll back around the edges of the Forest, towards Ringwood, and claim your medal, t-shirt and recovery product at the finish line.  Somerley House and Gardens are not usually open to the public; however as an added bonus, riders of the Wiggle New Forest Spring Sportive and supporters will have the chance to view some of the State rooms within the House and access to the Gardens on the event day.

name: Vale Vélo - Epic
description: The Wiggle Vale Velo is an early-season sportive designed to get you back into your best form and ready for the rest of the riding calendar, by taking you around the ever-popular cycling haven that is North Yorkshire.  The course allows you to chip away at the miles while tackling occasionally testing terrain. With almost 4,000ft of climbing over the Epic route, this is a quick and speedy course, presenting to you some of the best views the Vale of York and the Yorkshire Wolds have to offer, while also providing an early-year wake-up call for the legs.  Cycling in North Yorkshire  Starting from the York Auction Centre, the course heads straight out onto the roads of the stunning North Yorkshire district, while also threading through the quaint and typically pretty villages of the area. First, the route bears east, taking you past the historic battleground of Stamford Bridge, before heading up to Low Callis Wold.  At this point, riders of the Short course split off and head north to re-join the course at Leavening, while Epic and Standard riders continue east to pass through North Dalton, soon to take their own path north  Once again, the course splits shortly after, just before Sledmere House, sending Standard riders west as Epic riders continue to ride east even further, to the farthest point on the course in Rudston. Here, we start to head for home, and as the finish closes in, two final climbs lay in wait before the long, gradual descent back to York.  The Wiggle Vale Velo Sportive is ideal for those wanting to get some training in and, considering the distances, isn't too harsh on the legs. That said, there are a few nice and challenging climbs along the Epic route, so don't partake thinking it will be a ride in the park. It's not. It's a ride through the stunning North Yorkshire countryside.

name: South Downs Spring - Epic
description: If you haven’t blown the winter cobwebs off your bike with a fast and free-flowing ride this far into the year, the Sigma Sports South Downs Spring Sportive, set amongst the stunning South Downs of Sussex, is likely just the event to ease you back into the saddle.  Not forgetting this ride’s challenging hills, this South Downs Sportive matches great climbs with the best descents that sprawl through stunning open country lanes.  Kicking off in pretty Plumpton, the route heads east on unassuming back roads that can be taken at speed if so desired. As much as the hills on this route are a welcome challenge, you’ll be out of your saddle and counting on every last bit of winter training you have for the toughest ascents.  Flirting with the most infamous hills in the area, riders are taken around the base of some fearsome climbs but the route tends to stick to luxurious rolling roads tucked away from traffic. Exploring East Sussex, sleepy villages are taken in one by one before reaching the outskirts of Heathfield – but this ride stays true to its countryside routes as it soon reaches back into the wilderness.  Taking in a loop out past Five Ashes and back past High Hurstwood, you’ll be taken past Buxted and towards Uckfield on roads that remain mostly flat, quiet and long ranging. The route then leads north before crossing back into Mid-Sussex and turning south just before it crosses the River Ouse. A shining sun and helpful tailwind are enough to push you along for one last boost towards the finish line – which finishes on a mostly downward slope. You’ll cross the finish line feeling enthralled.

name: Spring Saddle Sportive - Epic
description: The heritage of the humble saddle is strong around the Newmarket area – albeit with a different type of riding as this sportive leads out from the Rowley Mile Racecourse of Newmarket Racecourses. Much like a horse racing course, the route is filled with flat and consistent terrain, leaving no excuse for stragglers to be behind by the first hurdle. You’ll cross through Suffolk, Cambridgeshire and Essex in this tri-county sportive, which begins by heading south, picking up the River Stour around Brinkley, which you’ll follow for a short while until reaching the outskirts of Haverhill. Taking in sleepy villages with their idyllic churches and greens typical of the area, you’ll press forward without the interruption from hills or climbing on this free-flowing ride. Entering into Essex for a few miles, you’ll pass through historic towns such as Thaxted, with its age-old buildings lining the High Street. Continuing on, it’s a simple case of chewing away the miles left to go as the flat scenery enables you to push on at your own pace. You’ll soon reach Suffolk again and cross the River Stour once more. A series of flat miles and pretty villages lie on the final straight between you and a finish

name: Green shoots of recovery
description: Spring in the beech woods of the Chilterns. Quite hilly

name: I'm Gonna Get Lit Up When The Lights Go Up In Surrey
description: Enjoy an extra hour of daylight exploring quiet lanes and pretty villages with a few classic Surrey hills

name: Flight from the South Downs
description: Seems like a lot of off-road bits. To the South Downs via Epsom Downs with an old airfield and perhaps tea and tapestry on the way back

name: East Sussex roads
description: Cycling south from the High Weald to the Ouse Valley

name: OAP tomorrow
description: lunch at The Red Lion at Breachwood Green

name: Big ring only
description: A quick ride around Biggin Hill. First ride was done using the big ring only. Traffic can be pretty bad with some cars passing by way too close. The downhill sections are nice though. Goes past Botley Hill Farm for a bit of tea, as well as the good ol' White Bear

name: Sandy in bed?
description: Up, around and back

name: Betjemanesque
description: Metroland and beyond. Into the Chilterns and then back

name: My Tring a ling
description: A winter warmer in the Chilterns

name: Plagiarising Mr Peters' Pub
description: Riding to the Rodings

name: Forest Way foray
description: Enjoy the company and local knowledge of West Kent CTC

name: Selling seashells on the seashore (80km version)
description: Revised from 100km down to 80km. Original ride is - Selling seashells on the seashore - 100 km

name: Longer and stronger with The Men of Kent
description: A longer ride through Kent to lunch at Rye Harbour#CTC

name: (Not) To the Tin Pot
description: Through Sandridge to lunch at Whitwell, back to Big Chef via Panshanger. No trains or pubs involved.

name: Croydon to West - loop
description: Not for beginners. The traffic can be bad

name: Harpenden - Cricketers Arms for lunch, Emily's Tea Shop for tea
description: Nice ride around Harpenden

name: London Cambridge return
description: Based on Allan Hutchinson's route

name: Croydon to richmond station - A roads
description: Very flat, but uses A roads

name: New Forest Summer Sportive - Short route
description: Short route for the Brewin Dolphin New Forest Summer Sportive

name: Bedford with N Bloom
description: Roads: Very smooth except for two 100 metre bits of gravel. There are always potholes in the UK unfortunately.Cars: Almost none except for 100 metres along an A road. Some cars at the end of the ride near the train station.Terrain: Despite the graph on Strava, the terrain is mostly flat.

name: Leith Hill and Box Hill combo
description: First tackling Leith Hill and then Box Hill

name: Around Hemel Hampsted
description: Cycling around Hemel Hampsted

name: St Albans 40k
description: Cycling around St Albans - 40km

name: St Albans 45k
description: Cycling around St Albans - 45km

name: Dorking 100
description: Goes down Box Hill but then goes up Leith Hill. The last hill back up is a killer

name: Luton Loop
description: Goes around St Albans and Luton. The A roads near Luton Station isn't pleasant. Need to revise route

name: From Balcombe to the South Downs
description: ~60 km and 700m climbing without an optional ascent of Ditchling Beacon. Lunch at Plumpton

name: Windmills in the Chilterns
description: Quite hilly

name: Down to the sea at Winchelsea
description: Through a bird reserve on a shingle spit and eventually towards the teashops at Rye. A few hills here

name: Castle Hedingham
description: Jam for tea

name: Lunch at Emily's Tea Shop in Whitwell
description: Ride through quiet countryside from St Albans to Harlington. Starts on Sustrans route from St Albans then on small roads via Ayot St Lawrence. A bit hilly but only one hard one into Harlington at the end

name: Blackwater blues
description: Through Essex lanes for a canal side lunch at The Paper Mill Cafe. Afternoon tea at Writtle College

name: Theme and variations
description: Back to the Chilterns. These lanes never fail to delight

name: London Revolution 2018 Day 1
description: The South London Leg - Cycle 160 kilometres through the iconic London sights, over the North Downs to Windsor Racecourse. Stage 1 - Cycle past the Shard and over Tower Bridge before witnessing the historic HMS Belfast. You’ll then venture South into Dulwich past Crystal Palace. Stage 2 - Follow the wheels of many Olympians who tackled these roads in the 2012 Games. Stage 3 - Your final leg into basecamp takes you through the idyllic Ewhurst, you’ll conquer Pitcher Hill one of the many beast’s along the North Downs

name: London Revolution 2018 Day 2
description: The North London Leg Buster - Cycle 140 kilometres from Windsor Racecourse, over the Chilterns and through Epping Forest, before finishing in Enfield. Stage 4 - Ride through beautiful Marlow, along the Thames Valley. Enjoy the scenic Buckinghamshire countryside before you hit the highs of the Chilterns. Stage 5 - Historic villages, buoyant market towns and traditional English pubs are all home to the idyllic countryside that you pedal on through, before hitting the lumpy Chilterns. Stage 6 - You’ll finish the ride in style, through the historic Epping Forest and back to Enfield to complete your full ‘revolution’ of our iconic capital city.

name: Surrey Hills Training
description: Good way to train for hills

name: Winter Training Route To Staplehurst & Back
description: Hayes-Shoreham-Plaxtol-Staplehurst This is the route used by the racing squad for winter training because it includes around 30 miles of flat terrain just 871m of climbing

Taking in a loop out past Five Ashes and back past High Hurstwood, you’ll be taken past Buxted and towards Uckfield on roads that remain mostly flat, quiet and long ranging. The route then leads north before crossing back into Mid-Sussex and turning south just before it crosses the River Ouse. A shining sun and helpful tailwind are enough to push you along for one last boost towards the finish line – which finishes on a mostly downward slope. You’ll cross the finish line feeling enthralled

name: The Cols de Rye (not)
description: A flat ride of about 100km over Romney Marsh taking in the delights of a nuclear power station

name: Just the long ride
description: The long ride to a cream tea

name: Croydon neighbourhood ride
description: A quick ride around Croydon, heading up Farthing Downs

name: Cycle tour around Hertfordshire
description: Lunch at the Cricketer

name: Peaslake fitness ride
description: Road cycle ride from Beckenham Green to Peaslake

name: Biggin Hill from Croydon
description: A quick ride around Biggin Hill, heading out from Croydon

name: Emitremmus Desrever - 2017
description: Emitremmus Desrever is our celebration of the end of summertime and the route is essentially the reverse of the middle-distance Start of summertime route. In addition to this, from 2011 we also offered a shorter Lite version of the Emitremmus. This event has grown to a point where we now have well over 400 entrants each year to this event and because of this, we encourage everyone to enter as early as possible to guarantee a place. Event Information We offer two different distances for this event. Both routes start and finish on the same roads but the middle follows different routes.

name: Emitremmus Desrever Lite - 2017
description: Emitremmus Desrever is our celebration of the end of summertime and the route is essentially the reverse of the middle-distance Start of summertime route. In addition to this, from 2011 we also offered a shorter Lite version of the Emitremmus. This event has grown to a point where we now have well over 400 entrants each year to this event and because of this, we encourage everyone to enter as early as possible to guarantee a place. Event Information We offer two different distances for this event. Both routes start and finish on the same roads but the middle follows different routes.

name: Box Hill loop
description: Starts and ends in Coulsdon

name: As your attorney, I recommend a bag of glue and some torq
description: Damien D's route around Chelmsford

name: Flat Kent ride
description: Could also be done in reverse

name: London to Cambridge
description: Following Paul F's route

name: Weald of Kent
description: Level 3 Route. 1000m of climbing concentrated at the beginning and end of the route, with approx 25 miles of flat section in the middle. Shoreham, Otford, Kemsing, Ightham, Ivy Hatch, Shipbourne, Underriver, Chiddingstone, Hever, Edenbridge, Tandridge, Oxted, Titsey Hill, Clarks Lane, Berrys Green and Downe.

name: Woldingham, Sundridge Hill Loop
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Woldingham – Knockholt – Cudham – Downe – Hayes This is one of our Saturday morning routes. It takes in some climbs as well as a fast section of Pilgrims Way. This is not for beginners. You should allow 3 hours but fitter riders will get round in 2hrs – 2hrs 30mins

name: Shop front to sea front
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Botley Hill – Godstone – Crawley – Waringlid – Brighton. A superb rural route all the way down to Brighton, taking in Devils Dyke instead of Ditchling Beacon

name: Cowden Loop
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Limpsfield – Lingfield – Cowden – Bough Beech – Ide Hill – Knockholt – Downe – Hayes. Lovely ride on quiet roads, some with surpringly good surfaces. Be prepared for some climbing near the end up Ide Hill and Star Hill

name: Winter Training Route To Staplehurst & Back
description: Difficulty: 4/5 Route overview: Hayes-Shoreham-Plaxtol-Staplehurst This is the route used by the racing squad for winter training because it includes around 30 miles of flat terrain just 871m of climbing

name: Turners Hill Loop
description: Difficulty: 3/4 Route overview: Hayes – Godstone – Smallfield – Copthorne – Turners Hill – East Grinstead – Lingfield – Tatsfield – Biggin Hill – Hayes. A fairly straight route out and back with steady climbing on the way and over Turners Hill before a quick return route

name: Bricabrac tea at finish
description: A shorter late winter ride

name: Surrey and Hampshire borders
description: Quiet lanes and pretty villages including a look at a 12th century siege castle

name: The narrow yellow ride
description: Narrow lanes in rolling north Kentish downland

name: Herts 4
description: Yet another part of Hertfordshire

name: An ellipse around Maidstone
description: Through the Garden of England and the North Downs stopping for lunch at the Cock Horse Inn, Detling

name: This is hardcore!
description: Not for winter. Includes a few kilometres through Bedgebury Forest – off road, but great surface. Some slopes but moderate. Lunch at Three Leg Cross

name: Chiltern Hills East
description: According to the CTC, we should expect a flawless performance

name: Suburban Breakout
description: The Central London CTC Audax. 100 km into Hertfordshire and back, rolling country, good company

name: I'll take you there
description: But where? Ride out from Tring and find out. A good day out in the Chilterns

name: Along the Thames
description: Threading through the Berkshire Downs to Benson for lunch

name: Along the Phoenix Way
description: Across the Vale of Aylesbury to Benson. Expect hills after lunch (or reserve the route)

name: The High Weald
description: Where East and West Sussex meet, including Ashdown Forest and the upper River Ouse

name: Sussex by the Sea?
description: Possibly. CTC's route from Sutton to Brighton

name: Medway Meanders
description: Some off-road sections. Probably better with gravel bikes

name: Chiltern Windmills
description: A hilly ride through the beechwoods to a Chiltern Church tea

name: Lots of lovely hills
description: Swooping up and down lanes in the East Sussex Weald

name: Out of Dorking
description: The hills and woods of Surrey in high summer, you'll have earned your afternoon tea at the end

name: Before the move 1
description: Favourite haunts revisited. Ride past stately homes and castles to lunch at The Wheatsheaf at Bough Beech

name: Out into Cambridgeshire
description: Wide open spaces for 65km. Afternoon tea at Wimpole Hall (National Trust)

name: Lanes and Byeways
description: Hidden parts of Hertfordshire, some of it may be unsurfaced but nothing too extreme – off road lite

name: Patience Bridge and Pigstye Green
description: The best of Essex lanes. Afternoon tea in the Nuclear Bunker

name: Single track mind, single track roads
description: In search of autumn down little known lanes

name: Somewhere in Hertfordshire

name: Favourite lanes, favourite pub, favourite tea

name: North Kent and the Hoo Peninsula

name: Cycle Paths in Hertfordshire: a brief introduction

name: Local man, local beers

name: Snakes Alive!
description: Through the lanes of Essex to The Viper for lunch
